title: EverWatt Energy Efficiency Certification - For Office Building Engineers
subtitle: Certification for energy efficiency in commercial office buildings
description: Validate your expertise in identifying and implementing energy efficiency measures for commercial office buildings. This certification covers HVAC, lighting, plug loads, building envelope, and tenant space considerations.

questions.question: In commercial office buildings, what percentage of total energy is typically consumed by HVAC systems?
questions.explanation: HVAC systems typically consume 40-55% of total energy in commercial office buildings. This is the largest single end use, making HVAC optimization the highest priority.

questions.question: An office building has a chiller that runs 24/7, but the building is only occupied 10 hours/day, 5 days/week. What is the most impactful measure?
questions.scenario: An office building's chiller runs continuously, but the building is only occupied Monday-Friday, 7 AM - 5 PM (10 hours/day). The chiller runs at full capacity even during unoccupied periods, weekends, and holidays.

options.text: Install scheduling controls and implement night/weekend setback

questions.explanation: Installing scheduling controls and implementing night/weekend setback can reduce HVAC energy by 20-40%. This addresses the specific issue of 24/7 operation when the building is only occupied 10 hours/day. Scheduling is typically the fastest payback measure for office buildings.

questions.question: An office building has 500 computers that run 24/7. Each computer uses 100W. What is the annual energy use if computers are turned off during non-business hours (reducing runtime from 168 to 50 hours/week)?
questions.explanation: Current: 500 √ó 100W = 50,000W = 50 kW √ó 168 hrs/week √ó 52 weeks = 436,800 kWh/year. With controls: 50 kW √ó 50 hrs/week √ó 52 weeks = 130,000 kWh/year. Savings: 306,800 kWh/year. At $0.12/kWh = $36,816/year savings.

questions.question: What is the typical energy savings potential for plug load controls in office buildings?
questions.explanation: Plug load controls (scheduling, occupancy-based, smart power strips) typically yield 15-30% savings of plug load energy in office buildings. This addresses the issue of computers, monitors, and other equipment running during unoccupied periods.

questions.question: An office building has single-pane windows. What is the typical energy savings potential from upgrading to double-pane low-E windows?
questions.explanation: Upgrading single-pane windows to double-pane low-E windows can reduce overall building energy by 10-20%. This addresses both heating and cooling loads and improves comfort. However, window replacement is capital-intensive, so it's often combined with other envelope improvements.

questions.question: What is the typical priority order for energy efficiency measures in office buildings?

options.text: HVAC Systems, Lighting, Building Envelope, Plug Loads
Lighting, HVAC, Plug Loads, Building Envelope
Building Envelope, HVAC, Lighting, Plug Loads
Plug Loads, Lighting, HVAC, Building Envelope

questions.explanation: HVAC systems are typically the highest priority (Very High) due to their large energy share (40-55%). Lighting is High priority. Building Envelope is High priority. Plug Loads are Medium-High priority.
